results.title: Montana
results.brief_description: Morgan Lane (Errol Flynn), an Australian sheepman arrives in Fort Humbolt, Montana ready to buy some land for grazing - his determination stemming from his father being driven off the land by cattlemen. His mission seems hard to achieve, especially when the suspicious locals are not ready to accept a stranger into their midst, and a sheep rancher at that. Lane faces opposition from cattle rancher Maria Singleton (Alexis Smith), a flame haired beauty who is initially attracted to the new stranger, until she discovers his motives. Singleton has a passionate aversion to sheepmen as her father, and her fiance lost their lives in a sheep and cattle war. Cast also includes Alexis Smith, S.Z. Sakall, Douglas Kennedy, James Brown and Ian MacDonald. Based on a novel by Ernest Haycock.

results.title: Montagnes Magiques = Magic Mountains
results.brief_description:
In this film montage Robert Enrico describes the enduring fascination of men for the mountains as well as the many relationship humanity has entertained with rock formations: from rock painting to health spa; from heretic stronghold (Montsegur) to Catholic pilgrimage (Lourdes) as well as the many research and scientific usages (observatories, solar stations).

Credits: Producer, J. Jacoupy ; director, Robert Enrico ; photography, Rene Mathelin ; music, Francois de Roubaix.

results.title: Mont Blanc: the fool killer
results.brief_description: Mont Blanc at 15,781 feet is the highest mountain in Europe and a graveyard to many reckless climbers. Frederick Burlingham, the director/photographer of this film, has scaled Mont Blanc four times. This film shows close-ups of Mont Blanc through the eyes of a telescope, focusing on some of the areas where many mountaineers have perished. Includes footage of Aiguille de Midi, a precipitous needle of 12,606 feet and a climbing party on some very tall crags. Interesting film from a historical point of view, notably the way the climbing party are dressed and how they are just roped together - very different from today’s climbers!

results.title: Monster fish
results.creator_credit: AFTRS, Matthew Duchesne and Polly Seddon
results.brief_description: A young girl, Alex (Jasmine Pease), struggles to understand her parent’s divorce and as her confusion mounts her obsession with stray animals, particularly fish, flourishes. As Alex develops a caring sensibility for her pet fish, she’s able to move on past her hurt to being a child once again.

results.title: Monsieur Vincent
results.brief_description:
The life and work of Saint Vincent de Paul, who was in conflict with the rich and powerful because of his pioneer work among the poor. Although the film had some financial backing from the catholic Church, this inspiring depiction of saintliness contains only a modicum of sermonizing. The beauty of the photography does not exclude the strakness of the poverty or the brutality of the age. Fresnay, growing from a young man to old age, carries even atheists along with him. Awards: Academy Awards (Oscars) 1948: Best foreign film ; Venice Film Festival (Mostra) 1948: Best actor for Pierre Fresnay. Reference: Bloomsbury Foreign Film Guide.

Credits: Director, Maurice Cloche ; writers, Jean Bernard-Luc, Jean Anouihl ; photography, Claude Renoir ; music, J. Grunenwald.
Cast: Pierre Fresnay, Aime Clariond, Pierre Dux, Jean Debucourt, Lise Delamare, Gabrielle Dorziat.

results.title: Monsieur Verdoux: a comedy of murder
results.creator_credit: Charles Chaplin Productions and Charles Chaplin
results.brief_description: Monsieur Verdoux (Charles Chaplin) has been working in a bank for thirty-five years when he finds himself out of a job in the Great Depression. Needing to support his invalid wife and child he begins to seduce, marry and then kill a series of rich women in order to maintain the standard of living he is used to. When eventually he is brought to trial, during the escalation of fascism and war in 1930s Europe, Monsieur Verdoux cannot see what he has done wrong given that all around him the world is celebrating mass murder and death. This acerbic and very dark comedy was a controversial disaster for Chaplin on its initial release. He was blacklisted as a “communist sympathiser” by the McCarthy-era witch-hunt in Hollywood, and “Monsieur Verdoux” was used as evidence against him at his trial. Over the years, however, the film has gained a reputation as one of the most subversive and cynical black comedies to have ever come out of Hollywood. The subject matter - serial murder, misogyny, anti-Capitalism - still has the power to shock an audience. Some of the main delights of this film are the range of excellent comic performances by Chaplin himself, Martha Raye and Isobel Elsom. The film was based on a true to life murder case and the idea for the film was suggested by Orson Welles.

results.title: Monsieur Pointu
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Rene Jodoin, Bernard Longpre and Andre Leduc
results.brief_description: Here is screen magic at its best. Virtuoso stage entertainer Monsieur Pointu (his real name is Paul Cormier, renowned beyond his native Quebec), becomes even more animated through the art of film animation. He and his violin are literally taken apart - head, feet, limbs, various items of stage attire, bow, strings, and box go into their own separate acts, with strange and amusing results. Film without words. (Four awards, including Oscar nomination, Hollywood)

results.title: Monsieur Bais
results.brief_description:
Charles Bais is a well-to-do architect married to Marthe, a harpsicord player. The day following Charles’ purchase of a handgun, Marthe is found dead in bed with a bullet wound to the heart. The murder investigation conducted by Judge Massot reveals that Charles used to enjoy a rather ecclectic sex life and that he was in the habit of sharing his mistresses with his good friend Docteur Noel. Judge Massot’s attention becomes increasingly drawn to one of Charles’ conquest: the mysterious Camille.

Credits: Producer, Jean Gauthier ; director, Claude Barma ; writer, Pierre Dumayet ; photography, Ghislain Cloquet ; music, W. A. Mozart.
Cast: Simone Signoret, Michel Vitold, Didier Haudepin, Anna Karina, Maurice Ronet, Georges Wilson, Gisele Grimm.
